Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation2: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat with my family lighting up with messages about our annual holiday trip. My mom’s text was clear: “We really want you there this year. It means a lot to everyone.” I could almost hear her hopeful voice, and I knew how much my presence mattered, especially to my younger brother who always looked up to me. At the same time, my work email pinged with a message from my manager, marked urgent. The leadership team needed my confirmation on a project detail for an external partner, and they were waiting for my reply to move forward. I could feel the pressure mounting—my family expecting me to be fully present and engaged, my colleagues counting on my quick response to keep things on track. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be a good sister and a reliable colleague at the same time, feeling the weight of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
